text: Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me. Patient: Yeah, no, you explained it, someone explained it that there’s - when chemo starts - it’ll be a blood test prior the chemo and a blood test after. And, uh, the leaving the timings out of it because I don’t really recall. And then, then roughly a week before the next cycle, there’ll be a blood test, then the chemo, and then, we’ll say within a week, I guess it’s another blood test. And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay?

text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Huh, I would say, sometimes it’s a five on my neck, especially when I turn it. Doctor: Okay. And so- Patient: Before, it was turning to the left and it was turning to the right because I wanted to start driving. But now, when I turn it to the left it seems like right there you can feel the bone. Doctor: So you’ve not been able to drive yet because you can’t twist your neck enough? Patient: Right. Family Member: And on your (voice) Patient: Or bend it backwards. The right side ain’t bothering me. It’s just that one that, well, the one that the screw came loose. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, any numbness or tingling? Patient: What? In my neck? Doctor: Your arms, your legs. Patient: No. And the only other thing that now and then is my shoulder blade from the day, from the first day that I was operated on. Or is it just present?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: The only place they run into problems is if somebody comes with you know five-hundred things in the bowel, and we’re putting this radiation in cancer, in terms of next to the bone cells, those people mostly get bone marrow problems. But in regard to you, I would expect probably not from the bone marrow. Family Member: Can you get him in this? Doctor: Well the German thing is you know unfortunately you’d have to pay for it. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it’s not a study. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They’re just taking it as uh pay as you go. Uh so we’ve talked before, and I know you have the means to do it. Uh they, so, I’d, I’d work with a group. There’s a group in Heidelberg, Germany, and there’s a group in a place called Bad Berka, which is, I could show it to you on a map, but it’s, it’s outside of Frankfurt. Patient: Um huh.. Doctor: It’s near, it’s in East Germany. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh those two groups have the biggest experience. The guy I know very well is in Bad Berka. Uh I think both groups though will take referrals, and then they take over and make the arrangements for folks to come, put you up, all the things. And the number they quoted me is about fifty-thousand bucks to do it. Um which by American standards, is incredibly cheap, but because you can’t get, take advantage of health insurance, you know.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
